Remember to go through the comments, because he clarifies his position at the end. * *TheÂ Guardian*'sÂ Kevin Anderson argues that [open web systems and the flexibility they bring to publishing are a boon to journalists](https://web.archive.org/web/20130412092018/http://strange.corante.com/2009/01/06/ok-open-systems-beat-great-closed-systems-every-time), not a threat. * And hereâ€™s a [journalist triggering a great discussion of what his job should look like](http://bydanielvictor.com/2009/01/06/how-i-want-to-redefine-my-role-and-the-readers-role-in-the-newspaper/), bearing these new tools in mind.Â  * Will the journalists that [publishers lay off in this recession](https://web.archive.org/web/20090217163956/http://www.paidcontent.co.uk/entry/419-more-laid-off-journos-becoming-entrepreneurs-new-model-for-local-news/) become their new competitors? * [RIP printed Exchange & Mart](http://privatefraser.wordpress.com/2009/01/07/sold-down-river/). Thatâ€™s the death knell of printed classified you can hear tolling.Â  * So, is it time for us to reach t[he fifth stage of grief](http://recoveringjournalist.typepad.com/recovering_journalist/2009/01/stage-five-acceptance.html) as we mourn the loss of our old way of working?
